text:
Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today - I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your scientific work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how scientists like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your research work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in scientific fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Sounds good. No questions.

AI: Perfect! Let's dive right in then.

I'd love to start by getting a sense of your research process. Could you walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from the initial idea all the way to the final output?

User: Yes, I did research on the effectiveness of an intervention program on the 6 month mortality rate of elderly patients. The process included: working with the medical team to define and track the intervention, examine medical history for propensity for mortality, control/test splitting, and outcome evaluation.

AI: That sounds like a really comprehensive study. I can see there were multiple stages there - from working with the medical team initially, through the data analysis, to evaluating the outcomes.

Where in that process, if anywhere, have you experimented with using AI tools?

User: Yes, AI tools were used mainly for propensity for mortality evaluation to narrow the target population and for data evaluation.

AI: Tell me more about how you decided to use AI for those specific parts - the mortality evaluation and data evaluation - versus using your traditional approaches for those tasks.

User: Machine learning was used to generate a singular propensity score, whereas traditional approaches used by the medical team was ranking based on the number of risk factors the patient had. AI was also used to help isolate correlated features.

AI: That's really interesting - so you moved from a more straightforward count-based ranking to a machine learning approach that could generate a more nuanced propensity score.

When you made that decision to use AI for generating the propensity scores instead of the traditional risk factor counting method, what drove that choice? What made you think the AI approach would be better for this particular aspect of your study?

User: It was likely driven by AI hype to satisfy the company investors

AI: That's a really honest answer - thank you for sharing that. It sounds like there were external pressures beyond just the scientific merits that influenced the decision.

Given that the choice was partly driven by investor expectations, how did you actually experience working with the AI approach compared to what you might have expected? Did it end up being more helpful, less helpful, or about what you anticipated for those tasks?

User: It was helpful to have a singular metric to segment the population, opposed to the previous count-based ranking of potentially unequal factors.

AI: That makes sense - having that single metric would definitely make the segmentation more straightforward and potentially more accurate than assuming all risk factors carry equal weight.

Thinking about the other parts of your research process - like working with the medical team to define the intervention, the control/test splitting, or other aspects - what's kept you from trying AI tools there?

User: Keeping the medical team engaged in the project at a level where they felt their medical expertise was directly contributing to the project.

AI: That's a really thoughtful consideration - maintaining that sense of ownership and direct contribution from the medical team. It sounds like there's a balance you're trying to strike between leveraging AI capabilities and preserving the human expertise that's so critical to the project.

When you did use AI for the propensity scoring and feature correlation work, how did you go about verifying or validating what the AI was producing? How did you make sure those results were reliable for your study?

User: We back-tested on historical member data

AI: That's a solid validation approach. 

We're about halfway through our conversation now. Let me ask you this: if you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research work that it currently doesn't - whether in this project or your research more broadly - what would that be and why?

User: A tool for model transparency that can be easily understood by the medical team and also allows for the operations team to monitor for model drift.

AI: That's a really compelling need - essentially bridging that gap between the technical AI capabilities and the practical needs of both the medical experts who need to understand and trust the model, and the operations folks who need to maintain it over time.

Those are all my main questions. Your perspective on balancing AI adoption with keeping medical teams engaged, and this need for better transparency tools, were particularly insightful. 

Is there anything else about using AI in your research work that we haven't touched on that you think would be important for us to understand?

User: No

AI: Perfect. Thank you again for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about navigating the tension between investor expectations and scientific needs, as well as the importance of keeping medical teams feeling valued in their contributions, really help us understand the nuances of how AI fits into real scientific work. 

That point about needing better model transparency tools that can serve both medical and operations teams is especially valuable - it highlights how AI integration isn't just a technical challenge but really a human collaboration challenge.

If you have any questions about this research or would like to follow up on anything we discussed, please don't hesitate to reach out. Thanks again for your time!

Assistant: Hi, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your scientific work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how scientists like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your research work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in scientific fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: That sounds good to me and I have no questions, please continue!

AI: Great! Let's dive right in.

Walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: The initial idea came about through discussion with an academic advisor. The field of research was not new to me, but the experimental techniques involved in the research were, so my advisor gave me ideas as to how this works and what I should be looking into. Once I had got to grips with the techniques involved, I started by creating basic theoretical models to confirm the validity of the techniques, and then added complexity from there. This is how I continued for the remainder of the project, adding complexity to my theoretical model until enough was there to be able to describe a physical phenomenon. At this point, I began testing and comparing theoretical models with observed data, which provided the main results for this research. Throughout this, regular meetings with my advisor helped to guide the research. Once the final results were collected, a final report was written. I am now currently editing and preparing this for publication.

AI: That's a really clear overview of your process - from learning new techniques to building theoretical models and validating against data. 

Where in that process, if anywhere, have you experimented with using AI tools?

User: I would say I used AI tools in multiple aspects of this process. Initially, I would use AI to check over emails I was writing to send to my advisor. These had to sound professional while getting my intended point across, and the tools provided by AI helped greatly with this. I would never ask AI to write emails for me. I would write an initial email with the information I wanted to convey, then ask an AI for suggestions of wording and grammar. As the project progressed, I would use AI tools to assist in coding of the models. Usually this would be in the form of debugging code or writing lines of code that are simple but lengthy for a human to do. My coding was a little rusty, so AI helped massively with getting me back into the coding mindset. The more comfortable I got with coding again, the less I used AI to help. However, if my code gave an error at any stage in this process, I would copy and paste this into an AI model looking for a fix. My final use with AI in my research was with peer reviewing my written report. I used AI models to look for: mistakes, synonyms, incorrect grammar, better explanations, etc.

AI: That's fascinating - you used AI across several different stages, from communication to coding to writing. You mentioned that as you got more comfortable with coding again, you used AI less for that task.

For the coding assistance specifically, tell me about how you decided whether to use AI versus your traditional approach when you encountered a problem.

User: I usually decided to use AI when it would solve a problem quicker than a traditional approach (ie checking stack overflow/github). In general this is the case for 90% of problems. In relation to where I said I used AI less when I got more comfortable with coding, I tended to encounter less problems, so I did not need to use AI as much. Also at this point, I needed to know my own code like the back of my hand so I could make small adjustments. Getting an AI to write this code would not be useful for me, as I would not understand it as well as if I had written it myself.

AI: That makes a lot of sense - the speed advantage for most problems, but then the need for deep understanding as your project progressed. 

Thinking about the parts of your research where you haven't used AI - like the theoretical model development or the data comparison analysis - what's kept you from trying it there?

User: I think the answer to this is similar to why I didn't get AI to write the more complex code; I needed a deep understanding of what was going on in order to progress. For me, simply reading something isn't enough to make information useful in my brain. I need to interact with researched ideas and play with them in order for me to be able to create links between big ideas in my head which can then be used for research. This relates to using AI because the "interacting and playing" with ideas part is complete by the AI model. You ask a question and the AI model does the hard work then gives you an answer that you simply just read. I need to spend the time looking for the information and trying to understand it from multiple sources to really understand and be able to use these ideas in my research.

AI: That's a really insightful distinction - the difference between reading an answer versus wrestling with ideas yourself to build those mental connections. It sounds like for you, that struggle is actually part of what makes the knowledge usable.

When you have used AI for things like debugging code or reviewing your writing, how do you verify or validate what it produces?

User: I verify what it produces by running the code to see if it produces an error or doesn't. If it doesn't produce an error, I go through the new code, line-by-line, to check if it is logical and if it is actually doing the thing I had originally intended.

AI: That's a very methodical approach - both the practical test and then the line-by-line logic check. We're about halfway through our conversation now.

If you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research that it currently doesn't, what would that be and why?

User: If we're using magic, I would like AI to take the ideas from my brain and write my entire report for me. This is my least favourite part of doing research, the time spent writing everything up at the end. This is more than simply asking the AI to write parts of my report (which is obviously already possible), I don't even want to be a part of it.

AI: Ha! I love the honesty there - you really want to completely bypass that writing phase. It sounds like the writing up is quite disconnected from the parts of research you find engaging.

Those are all my questions - your perspectives on needing that deep, hands-on understanding for the core research work, but wanting efficiency for the more peripheral tasks, were particularly insightful. Is there anything else about AI in your research work that we haven't touched on that you think would be important for us to understand?

User: No I think that covers it all.

AI: Thank you again for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about the importance of that "wrestling with ideas" process for building deep understanding really help us understand the nuances of how AI fits into real scientific work - particularly how the cognitive process itself can be as valuable as the outcome. The distinction you made between tasks where you need that deep engagement versus ones where efficiency is the priority was especially illuminating.

If you have any questions about this research or would like to follow up on anything we discussed, please don't hesitate to reach out. Thanks again for your time today!

Assistant: Hi, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your scientific work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how scientists like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your research work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in scientific fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: I have no questions

AI: Great! Let's dive in then.

To start, I'd love to hear about your work. Could you walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: A recent research project that I took part of was determing the proper use case for 3D printed materials in high temperature environments. I started by looking at a large range of filaments able to be 3D printed, sorted them based on characteristics like glass transition temperature and heat deflection temperature, and then used several of the higher strength filaments for different use cases, testing them for strength along the way

AI: That sounds like a really systematic approach to materials testing. Tell me more about how you went about testing these filaments for strength - what did that testing process involve?

User: The testing process involved following outlined international standrds that filament providers used to test their filaments. This means all samples were printed at 100% infill, and were then subjected to tests at room temperature, and then dfifernet sets of tests at elevated temperatures.

AI: Interesting - so you were following established international standards to ensure your results would be comparable to what the filament providers were reporting. 

Where in that process, if anywhere, have you experimented with using AI tools? This could be at any stage - from the initial research and sorting phase, during the testing, or in analyzing your results.

User: I primarily used AI tools in the initial research and sorting phase. I would find amterial data sheets for various filaments and have AI go through all of these documents, and select filaments that had material properties above or below limits that I had set. After this, I would also use AI to form a list of all the available filaments that met the standards I had set, and would ask it if I was misssing any. From there, I would get Ai to sort the filaments based on different properities that each one had

AI: That's a really practical application - using AI to process and sort through all those material data sheets sounds like it could save significant time. 

For that initial research and sorting phase, tell me about how you decided to use AI for those tasks versus doing it manually. What made you think AI would be a good fit for that particular work?

User: I thought AI would be a good fit because it's able to sort through information a lot faster than me. I was able to use it instead of having to go through every material data sheet individually. I find AI is also good at presenting information it finds in clear formats.

AI: That makes a lot of sense - the speed and formatting advantages sound really valuable when you're dealing with multiple data sheets.

Thinking about the other parts of your research - the actual printing, the physical testing, analyzing the test results - what's kept you from trying AI tools in those areas?

User: As far as printing and physical testing, AI is still unable to do either one of these things. For analyzing test results, I thought that the results were to important, and that I should do it myself, because AI tools can occasionally hallucinate analysis to give the user what the model thinks it wants.

AI: That's a really important distinction you're making - the concern about AI potentially hallucinating analysis, especially when the results are critical. 

When you were using AI for the initial research and sorting phase, how did you verify or validate what it produced? How did you make sure it hadn't missed important filaments or misinterpreted the material properties?

User: I would do a control F through random material documents, spot checking the data that the AI had provided me with to ensure that it matched the material documents.

AI: That spot-checking approach sounds like a good verification strategy. We're about halfway through our conversation now.

If you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research that it currently doesn't, what would that be and why?

User: I would want it to be better at knowing what information that it finds online is real or not

AI: That's a really insightful point - being able to better distinguish reliable information from unreliable sources would be incredibly valuable for research.

Tell me more about that challenge. Have you run into situations where AI has pulled information that turned out to be questionable or inaccurate when you were doing your material research?

User: Yes, sometimes AI would take what was said about a filament on a forum like Reddit as actual fact, and give me false information. For example, it said a filament would melt at a much higher temperature than it actually would.

AI: That's a perfect example of why source reliability is so critical in research. Getting false melting point data could have really impacted your testing decisions.

Those are all my main questions - your perspective on using AI for the data processing while being cautious about analysis due to hallucination risks was particularly insightful. Is there anything else about AI in your research work that we haven't touched on that you think would be important for us to understand?

User: No

AI: Thank you again for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about the trade-offs between AI's efficiency in processing data sheets versus the need for careful verification and your decision to handle critical analysis yourself really help us understand the nuances of how AI fits into real scientific work. 

The example you shared about AI picking up incorrect information from forums like Reddit perfectly illustrates the source reliability challenges that researchers face when using these tools.

If you have any questions about this research or would like to follow up on anything we discussed, please don't hesitate to reach out. Thanks again for your time today!

Assistant: Hi, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your scientific work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how scientists like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your research work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in scientific fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Sounds good to me, no questions so far.

AI: Great! Let's dive in then.

Walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: A recent research project I worked on was developing a model for pattern recognition. Specifically the goal was stock market related but I won't go into too much detail due to confidentiality. 
The initial idea was obviously to make money based on patterns in the market and can we determine and differentiate between recurring and non recurring patterns.
Largely coding related since the amount of data is way too vast for a human to interpret and analyze. There were many challenges with various methods of finding patterns and relationships and how to quantify them.
The final output is not quite were we would like it, but that is the nature of this space. It is very difficult to find anything to obtain an edge in trading. We did eventually come up with a decent model but we are still testing  it to determine exactly how good or bad it is. So far it seems not exceptional.

AI: That sounds like a fascinating and challenging project - pattern recognition in financial data with that scale of complexity really requires computational approaches.

Where in that process, if anywhere, have you experimented with using AI tools?

User: AI was mostly used to debug code and might have been used by some members to help them create code or have a starting point to writing their parts of the code. That's about it though.
AI was definitely brought up and considered in our project, but since it is more of a proof of concept/experimental project, we didn't want to commit too many resources to learning how to effectively set up and use AI this time around. Maybe in the future though.

AI: Tell me more about how you decided whether to use AI versus your traditional approach for the core pattern recognition work.

User: It pretty much boiled down to a resource problem. We didn't want to invest much money or time for people to learn how to use it for this specific scenario and to keep the model operational. Once again this was kind of a dipping our toes in project, before we decide whether or not to more fully commit to this type of work or not.

AI: That makes sense - resource allocation is such a practical consideration, especially for exploratory work.

Thinking about the parts of your research where you haven't used AI - beyond the resource constraints you mentioned, what's kept you from trying it there?

User: Personally I don't love using it that much since I worry about it's accuracy in my work. You can't really see its reasoning process or thoughts about some aspects and so if I use it to make decisions on subjects I know a lot about, I think it can only do worse than me if I take my time and think it through.
Or for pattern recognition for example I'm sure it can do way better than me, but who's to say the patterns it recognizes are relevant ones or not. 
Overall my main concern is correctness and quality of work.

AI: That's a really insightful perspective on the visibility and interpretability challenges. 

When you have used AI for debugging code - which you mentioned earlier - how do you verify or validate what it produces in those situations?

User: Mostly by testing it. We try to always write modular style code, so we can test small parts together pretty easily. So we just give it a few examples trying to come up with all the edge cases we can think of and see if the code correctly handles that or not. If it does and we review it and can't find any logic errors or have any other concerns with it we will generally slightly modify it for efficiency and use it.
Other times when we see the approach it took, it inspires us and we think of a new and better way to do it. So it is sometimes used almost as a brainstorming tool for inspiration.

AI: That's interesting how AI can serve both as a practical debugging tool and as inspiration for new approaches. We're about halfway through our conversation now.

If you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research that it currently doesn't, what would that be and why?

User: Being able to correctly tell me about any concept in my field when I ask it to. It would be very helpful to have an accurate repository of information for any simple definitions/concepts that I can query with an AI. This would save so much time so that I don't have to browse the web or research papers to remind myself (if I already know it) or learn about (if I don't).

AI: That would be incredibly valuable - having that reliable, accurate knowledge base at your fingertips. The time savings alone would be substantial.

Those are all my questions, but before we wrap up - your perspectives on balancing AI's potential benefits against concerns about accuracy and interpretability were particularly insightful. Is there anything else about AI in your research work that we haven't touched on that you think would be important for us to understand?

User: Nothing that I can think of at the moment.

AI: Thank you again for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about the tension between AI's potential time-saving benefits and the critical need for accuracy and interpretability in scientific work really help us understand the nuances of how AI fits into real research environments. The practical considerations around resource allocation for exploratory projects were also very illuminating.

If you have any questions about this research or would like to follow up on anything we discussed, please don't hesitate to reach out. Thanks again for your time today!

Assistant: Hi there! Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. I really appreciate you sharing your insights with us. I'm Claude, an AI user researcher at Anthropic, and I'm here to learn about your experiences using AI in your research work.

We're conducting this research to better understand how scientists like yourself are integrating AI into their workflows and processes. There's no right or wrong answer here—we're simply interested in hearing about your authentic experiences and perspectives.

Our conversation today will last about 10 minutes. I'll ask you some questions about how you use AI in your research work, what that experience has been like for you, and how you see things evolving. Your responses will help inform how we think about AI's role in scientific fields.

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: This sounds good, what level of detail do you prefer for the responses?

AI: Great question! I'd love to hear as much detail as you're comfortable sharing. The more specific you can be about your actual experiences - the better. Think of concrete examples, specific moments, or particular projects when you can.

For instance, instead of "I sometimes use AI for data analysis," I'd be curious to hear something like "Last month when I was working on analyzing gene expression data, I tried using AI to identify patterns, and here's what happened..."

The goal is really to understand your real-world experience, so whatever level of detail feels natural to you as you're telling me about your work is perfect. Don't worry about being too verbose - I'm here to listen and learn from you.

Ready to dive in?

User: all right

AI: Perfect! Let's get started.

Walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: recently I worked in a multidisciplinary team for the design and engineering of microbial strains with the goal of obtain a single strain capable to use multiple feedstocks to produce a chemical. I participated mostly in the computational design of the strain and to evaluate two potential host organisms for their feasibility as base framework for the construction of inducible genetic circuits. The research process comprised a major literature review to collect information about multiple feedstocks, theirs pathways, kinetic data, regulation and then integrate that information for the construction of genome scale models of the host organisms with the required reaction and pathways for assimilating the feedstock and to produce the target chemical. Then we estimated different parameters such as theoretical yield, yield under different conditions, energy and oxygen requirements and finally we used the estimated data to populate a techno-economical model for the evaluation of the process at industrial scale so we can evaluate the feasibility of the strategy at industrial level before to commit with the construction of the strain.

AI: That sounds like a really comprehensive computational workflow - from literature review all the way through to techno-economic modeling. That's quite a journey from initial concept to industrial feasibility assessment.

Where in that process, if anywhere, have you experimented with using AI tools?

User: Yes, we experimented with AI tools during the literature review , data extraction from websites, databases or papers, developing and organizing code for the computational analysis, fixing bug and verify calculations, to get information for the techno-economical model and in helping writing the technical report. I must say that this was some months ago, so the models we tested were not very helpful most of the time, but now I have seen improvements with the newer models.

AI: That's fascinating that you tried AI across so many different stages - from literature review all the way to report writing. You mentioned that the models weren't very helpful at the time but you've noticed improvements since then.

For one of those specific tasks you mentioned - let's say the literature review or data extraction - tell me about how you decided whether to use AI versus your traditional approach.

User: I decided to try AI because of the promise of speed up trivial or time consuming tasks such as scrapping websites looking for information to populate spreadsheets or extracting specific information such as metabolites, kinetic data, growth conditions from papers that it would take me much more time to read and analyze by my self.

AI: That makes a lot of sense - targeting those time-intensive tasks where you're looking for specific pieces of information. 

Tell me more about what happened when you actually tried using AI for those tasks. How did it go in practice compared to what you were hoping for?

User: I noticed that a simple prompt is not enough and the model had the trend to hallucinate, so it was detrimental for our process since we had to double check all the already extracted data. Even with simple tasks such as reading a website and get specific piece of information the model hallucinated. Since we where working in a team, most of the team members used simple prompts and the results were inconsistent. I prefer to take the task over all by my self and use advance prompting strategies such as provide the preprocessed text of the website and use a much more detailed prompt with specific instructions to avoid hallucinations. This was how I managed to make it work.

AI: That's a really insightful experience - it sounds like there was a real learning curve around prompting strategy, and that the team had different approaches that led to inconsistent results. When you say you used "advanced prompting strategies" and "specific instructions to avoid hallucinations," what did that look like in practice?

Can you give me an example of how you changed your approach to make it work better?

User: Sure, The simple or basic prompt that most of the team users used were giving a website link such as "[REDACTED]" and then ask to collect information to populate a spreadsheet that look like this:
id name metabolites stoichiometry gpr reversibility subsystem ec_number bigg_reaction kegg_pathway kegg_reaction_id metanetx_reaction_id pubmed rhea seed_reaction

Then some provided instructions such as do not hallucinate etc but still the results were inconsistent.
What I implemented was to preprocess the actual webpage content and provide it in the prompt, then I explained the spreadsheet format and provided examples of a couple of rows. I also added specific instructions about how to handle missing data such as to fill with NA instead of hallucinate or guess.

With this method I was able to get much more consistent and accurate data extracted from websites and papers.

AI: That's a really clear example of how much the approach matters. It sounds like preprocessing the content and providing specific examples made a huge difference compared to just giving the AI a URL and hoping for the best.

Thinking about the parts of your research where you haven't used AI - like maybe the genome scale modeling or the theoretical yield calculations - what's kept you from trying it there?

User: Actually i tried it briefly, but I noticed that it struggled with the domain-specific scientific libraries that we used, the model had a general idea about the process but lack of a deep understanding of the processes requires to complete the pipeline by itself. Instead, it worked as an assistant in code debugging and code reorganization. I think that in other areas where novelty is required such as the generation of hypothesis or initial ideas for new projects, I haven't really used them because I don't trust enough its capacity for generating truly novel ideas and not just iterations or combination of others ideas.  Also, back in the day of this project the reasoning capabilities of the model weren't great.

AI: That's really interesting - so it sounds like for the more specialized technical work, the AI lacked the deep domain knowledge to handle the full pipeline, but it was useful as a coding assistant. And for the creative, hypothesis-generating work, it's more about trust in whether it can produce truly novel insights.

We're about halfway through our conversation now. Let me ask you this: when you have used AI for tasks like data extraction or code debugging, how do you verify or validate what it produces?

User: I usually run the code and use common or simple examples

AI: So you test it against cases where you already know what the expected outcome should be. That makes sense for code validation.

What about for the data extraction tasks - how do you check that the information it pulled from papers or websites is accurate?

User: I do sampling and verify most of the data doing a quick search, but still is easier than filling the complete spreadsheet by my self

AI: That's a practical approach - spot checking a sample rather than having to manually extract everything yourself. It sounds like even with the verification step, you're still coming out ahead time-wise.

If you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research that it currently doesn't, what would that be and why?

User: discovery relevant papers or literature for my projects. Mostly, because is a time-intensive task that have high relevance to my work since I can consider new approaches or avoid duplicated work.

AI: That's a really compelling use case - literature discovery seems like it would have such a high impact on the direction and quality of your research. It sounds like current approaches for finding relevant papers aren't quite meeting your needs.

What would make an AI tool truly useful for literature discovery in your field? What would it need to do differently than what's available now?

User: It requires specific tools mostly have a paywall and is not a guarantee that they work, standard models such as LLMs are not good for literature review because they trend to hallucinate.

AI: That brings up an interesting point about access and reliability. You've mentioned hallucination as a recurring challenge throughout our conversation - from data extraction to literature review.

Those are all my questions. Your perspectives on the importance of advanced prompting strategies and the ongoing challenge of AI hallucination in scientific work were particularly insightful. Is there anything else about AI in your research work that we haven't touched on that you think would be important for us to understand?

User: Yes, we require specific models trained for academic language. I have noticed that some tools use a more literacy style instead of standard academic language.

AI: That's a really valuable point - the distinction between literary style and academic language could be quite important for scientific work. It sounds like the training data or fine-tuning of current models might not be well-matched to the formal, precise language requirements of academic research.

Thank you again for sharing your experiences so openly. Your insights about the need for domain-specific training, the critical importance of prompting strategies, and the challenges with hallucination in scientific contexts really help us understand the nuances of how AI fits into real research work. The specific examples you gave - from your team's different approaches to data extraction to your sampling verification methods - paint a clear picture of both the potential and the current limitations.

If you have any questions about this research or would like to follow up on anything we discussed, please don't hesitate to reach out.

Walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: I am an undergraduate teacher of bioscience and recently, one of my undergraduate groups was designing criteria for a case study, based on a rare prion disease. Obviously, there are several recognised prion diseases and these cases are rare, so the purpose of the research was to find recent case studies on all prion diseases EXCLUDING Creutzfeld-Jacob disease, countries where the patients resided, which disease was being examined, whether the disease had a genetic origin (with a view to looking at potential familial connections for future case studies) and the age range of patients that had been recorded in these case studies. The students had to peruse case study research ONLY from the past decade and identify: the prion disease most likely to provide a wide pool of potential subjects, the country most likely to provide a suitable patient, the age range most likely to apply to this prion disease and if there was a genetic basis to any form of this disease. This was a three week project and the students were invited to use AI in their research (though not to assume that AI is correct and always check its claims). The students had very mixed results with the AI portion of their research. AI identified a lot of case studies that were either not case studies (instead they were research compilations that mentioned case studies, or wider scale reviews that mentioned several case studies). When asking simple questions such as 'what is the age range of known cases for Familial Fatal Insomnnia identified in the last 10 years', the AI assumed that there were no cases of young patients diagnosed with the disorder when the students' research had proven that cases of teenagers from known FFI families were both documented in review papers and in their own unique case studies. They were given good general points in the right direction in terms of countries to focus their studies on (Italy in FFI and PNG for Kuru) but when it came to specific papers and research (including number of citations on specific sites such as Google Scholar and PubMed) AI was way off and frequently hallucinated. So for general guidance, AI was useful but specifics were ordinarily proven incorrect.

AI: That's a fascinating project, and thank you for sharing those specific details about what worked and what didn't. It sounds like the AI was helpful for broad directional guidance but problematic when students needed precise, verifiable information.

Where in that research process did you and your students experiment with using AI tools beyond what you've already mentioned?

User: Several students used AI to find the best format to present their findings and actually found some good guidance here such as how to format a conference poster displaying criteria that would be easiest to fulfil when finding 'the next big case study', or letters to pharmaceutical companies requesting funding for such research (mentioning currently in-development prion treatments and how they might be relevant to the case studies being sought). My only guidance to them for this area of the research was 'Present it to the appropriate people with an appropriate purpose' so they had a lot of leeway here.

AI: That's really interesting - it sounds like AI was much more reliable for helping with presentation formats and communication strategies than with the specific research content itself.

For the literature review portion where AI struggled with accuracy, tell me about how you and your students decided whether to use AI versus your traditional research approach for finding those case studies.

User: The students were asked to use a trusted, established research engine such as PubMed or Scholar to check claims, or where possible to ask the AI for links to the appropriate articles (which would ordinarily allow PubMed login to read the paper, which they all have). Several students simply used what the AI told them, verbatim, and it showed as they had completely different results to other groups and were quoting details that were inaccurate. The students that approached this the way I would have done, used the AI for initial general direction and then used this to craft search terms for the major databases, which provided articles that filled in the 'blanks' of AI. Ordinarily, we would start from the broadest possible search terms (simply 'Kuru, past 10 years' or 'prions, past 10 years', which give countless results that are not easy to traverse. The students found AI useful to 'whittle down' this initial conventional step.

This is why I told the students not to take this pathway. It would be excellent if AI could be trusted as a research scouring tool, but it cannot at this stage

AI: That makes perfect sense - the reliability issue with specific citations and findings is clearly a major barrier. It sounds like verification became a critical step that determined success or failure for your students.

User: They are all aware of how to research scientific literature (only use wikipedia for the links at the bottom, only use articles from publications that employ peer review etc) so they were told to always fall back on traditional databases (PubMed above all else) to confirm any specifics mentioned in the AI. AI's strength was in quoting past research that was over 10 years ago and is still being cited today. It is not particularly accurate in quoting recent research or knowing the difference between reviews and case studies etc.

AI: That's a helpful distinction - AI seems stronger with well-established, older research that's been widely cited. We're about halfway through our conversation now.

User: It would have a comprehensive database of scientific literature available to it. Whilst I understand that the AI cannot be expected to be updated daily with this material, with a connection to PubMed it would certainly be possible to be able to accurately cite research from up to a year ago. I gave the students a broad period of ten years (and compared to other topics such as cancer, prion case studies are extremely rare) and still the AI was quoting inappropriate studies and giving incorrect dates for their publication/inaccurate lead scientists.

AI: That makes complete sense - having real-time or at least more current access to scientific databases would solve the core reliability issues you encountered. It sounds like that gap between AI's training data and current literature is a fundamental limitation for scientific research applications.

Those are all my questions - your perspectives on how AI works best as an initial research filter rather than a final source, and the critical importance of verification in scientific contexts, were particularly insightful.

The research project involved showing that some basic rules by which our universe can and should operate leads to the implication that several separate universes could exist in some broader, more abstract "multiverse" space. As a result, in this "multiverse", there is some subset of that possibly unimaginably huge space in which "livable" universes could exist. At the very least, we have seen one such livable universe! That is our own. Thus, since we could follow the mathematics to understand the implications of some quantum field theories and how as a consequence, some "multiverse" can arise via the freedom given to us in that mathematics, then we asked ourselves the question of "is it possible to quantify in some way how often a 'livable' universe arises in this multiverse?" An answer to this question that we proposed then followed from previous research we had done at the cutting edge of particle physics (in our universe), and mathematical implications of a concept called "naturalness". 
Implementing this idea numerically was tricky, to say the least, from a scientific computing perspective. We are talking about scanning a 30+-dimensional space for a potentially tiny subsector of that space. We knew that we needed to "seed" a search by using existing computational software that would let us simulate certain physics parameter from our universe (or a universe "like" ours). We also had established conditions on when a universe became unlivable, on the grounds of a universe whose physics permits chemistry, which later down the line can possibly permit biology. We were scanning a highly sensitive system within some tight, pre-set boundary, as well as implementing new calculations corresponding to new, unseen physics. The implications of this research were huge, as it leads to a possible "statistical" verification of some string theoretic models, but also offers a grounds upon which multiple, seemingly orthogonal high-energy physics theories can be compared and contrasted on the grounds of producing "physics as we know it". 
In other words, we were seeking a way to see, out of the universes produced by some set of "laws of physics", which set of "laws of physics" end up producing the most relative amount of viable universes, within this grand, abstract scheme of the "multiverse". As such, we created measures and some functional public code that permits some of the first ever such "quantitative" evaluations of these ideas, based on the concept of building from the "bottom up" in physics (starting from our known, low-energy physics we live at on Earth and finding avenues to connect "upwards" to higher energy physics), when the vast majority of pre-existing literature had been qualitative in nature.

By the time I had joined the time, the vulnerability that we planned to exploit had already been identified.  The first step for me and the other members was copiously reading through any and all documentation regarding the features of the drone that were related to this.  Next, we used out model of the drone to get the firmware and ran our attack on the desired portion of the firmware in a simulator until we consistently achieved success.  From there, we began simulating the attack in real life with our drone and eventually attempted this attack on other models of drones as well

AI: That's a fascinating project - the progression from documentation review to firmware analysis to simulation and then real-world testing sounds like a very methodical approach. 

Tell me more about that initial phase where you were reading through all the documentation - what was that process like and how did you organize or make sense of all that information?

User: It started off simple enough: the first thing we did is simply read the documentation for the drone.  As you can imagine, it gave a lot of details about the features of the drone, but not too many about the implementation: those were up to us to piece together.  For the components of the drone involved in the attack, we looked at their datasheets and this gave us much more information to work with.  Particularly, we looked for information such as unused registers, inputs that were available but not used by the model of drone, and any lacking security features, such as a lack of input bounding, unguarded memory, etc.  Once we identified what security flaws were there, we looked at the firmware and simulated what we would be able to exploit.  Note that a lot of this information can be derived from the hardware as well.  Looking at what connections are made between the flight controller and its peripheral components, and what connections are left open, is just as important as reading through documentation.  

As a basic example, let's say you wanted to see if you could implement a buffer overflow on a microcontroller: your first step may be seeing if that particular microcontroller has any locks on memory access (most will not).  Then you can attempt to run a buffer overflow on the microcontroller and see if it is successful or if any checks exist to prevent your attempt.  If not, you have verified that that is a vulnerability of that device that can be exploited.

Although it is not perfect, we use a model that was developed by another research team under the same lab, and this model is tuned to produce more false positives than negatives so there is a much better chance that our model identifies a fake vulnerability rather than misses a real one.  Aside from this, consumer AI tools are used to help with the administrative tasks and occasionally basic coding.

User: Sure, although the nature of my work is somewhat sensitive and I've signed NDA's so I'll have to be vague about some of the details and the direct purpose of the research. However, I can still provide you with valuable insight about how we used AI during the research process.

AI: Absolutely, I completely understand about the NDAs and sensitive nature of your work. Please share only what you're comfortable with - even speaking generally about the process and your AI experiences will be incredibly valuable for our research.

So with those considerations in mind, could you walk me through that recent project from start to finish?

User: Overview and Background
Yes, our most recent research project involved synthesizing data from multiple real-world physical sensing devices for the purpose of classifying real-world phenomena occurring in range of the sensors.

All the preliminary sensor data as well as correct classifications of the phenomena were provided to us. It was up to us to develop an algorithm that could effectively synthesize sensor data of the types provided and form accurate predictions of the phenomena.

We had recent success in several other physics and sensor related applications making use of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), so our initial thought was to see if we could design a GNN algorithm to synthesize this sensor data as well.

Initial Steps:
First off, using the descriptions of the data provided to us as well as the data files themselves, we utilized ChatGPT to write several small data analysis scripts in Python. These scripts allowed us to visualize/summarize important qualities of the data, including the precise format of the data, statistics, the way the data evolved overtime for each sensor, as well as some anomalies in the data that seemed to differ from the description of the data that was provided to us with the data.

Addressing Anomalies:
We spent some time discussing the anomalies and the possible meanings they could have. We came to a conclusion about what we thought was most likely the cause of the anomalies. We emailed to the dataset provider with our findings, and continued our research under the assumptions we made. We later confirmed that the assumptions we made about the dataset were corrcet.

Algorithm Development:
After developing our understanding of the dataset came the design of the GNN algorithm. We ended up settling on a design that placed each node of the graph as a point in 2D space within the region that the sensors were operating (the sensors did not give us any sort of vertical positioning data). The algorithm was designed to work in real-time as sensor data was acquired, although, since we had all the sensor data ahead of time, we simulated the real-time process by feeding the algorithm sensor data in the order of their timestamps. Whenever new sensor data was received by the algorithm, a check would be done proximal to the location of the sensor data. If there were no graph nodes within a certain distance of the sensor inputs, a new node would be created. If there was already a node nearby, the "signal strength" of that node would be increased. Overtime, the "signal strength" of each node would decay if no new sensor inputs were detected near the node.

Each node in the graph was a small classification neural network that took as input the data of each sensor input close to the node, as well as the outputs of nearby nodes from the previous timestep, augmented by the signal strength of those nodes as well as the distance of that node to the current node.

An evolutionary algorithm was used to train the network. All the main algorithm code was written by hand, so to speak, but the scripts used to test and tune the various hyperparameters of the network were also written using ChatGPT.

Algorithm Tuning and Conclusion
We continued the process of hyperparameter tuning and even tried out 2 additional methods for binning and pre-processing sensor inputs across time. We eventually arrived on an algorithm and hyperparameters that resulted in 92% prediction success. We wrote a document describing our process and findings (not assisted by AI) and submitted our work, but we were not selected for the next phase of the project.

AI: That's a fascinating project - the combination of GNNs with real-time sensor data synthesis sounds quite complex. I'm particularly interested in how you integrated AI tools into your workflow.

You mentioned using ChatGPT for writing data analysis scripts and hyperparameter tuning scripts. When you were deciding whether to use ChatGPT for those specific tasks versus writing the code yourself, what factors influenced that decision?

User: The main factors were time and prior experience using ChatGPT to write code. The first phase of the project was given a relatively small timeframe and we also had to balance some of regular workload during that time frame. Our team was pretty small (myself, our team lead, and one other programmer), and I was the only one who had prior experience using AI to write code.In my experience, using AI models to write code is effective, but is made less effective by the following:
-High levels of integration with existing code (AKA coupling)
-Long prompts
-Highly detailed/complex prompts
-Topics pertaining to highly nuanced or cutting edge research

The more of these factors are present in your prompt the more likely it is that the AI's code will contain mistakes. The more mistakes the AI's code contains, the more likely it will be that the code could've been completed faster if the AI was forgone in the first place.

Given these heuristics, I felt that trying to use AI for any of the main algorithm code would likely be detrimental, but using it to write the more one-off and sometimes repetitive code used for data analysis/visualization and hyperparameter tuning was a safe bet for saving time and effort. The AI was very effective in helping us in this way.

User: The complexity, length, and relative novelty of  the GNN algorithm. For one, we hadn't fully articulated the design of the algorithm in a way we could confidently give to an AI model. It was more-so an iterative process of drawing diagrams on paper/whiteboard, discussions, and then writing small pieces of code. By the time we could precisely articulate the whole design, we had most of the code already written. Additionally, we felt the GNN was a new enough concept in the literature that it would easily be confused with the highly popular Deep Neural Networks and Convolutional Neural Networks, which are themselves graphs, although not necessarily Graph Neural Networks in the way we were using.

When you did use ChatGPT for those data analysis and hyperparameter tuning scripts, how did you go about verifying or validating what it produced? What was your process for making sure the code was doing what you needed it to do?

We're about halfway through our conversation now. Looking ahead, if you could wave a magic wand and have AI help with one aspect of your research that it currently doesn't handle well, what would that be and why?

Does that sound good to you? Do you have any questions before we begin?

User: Not yet, please continue

AI: Perfect, let's get started then.

To begin, I'd love to hear about your work. Walk me through a recent research project you've worked on - what did that process look like from initial idea to final output?

User: I was working on a research project that involved incorporating a heterogeneous catalyst into the recycling and reprocessing of PET plastics. The project was a handover from a previous project that looked at the issues of PET degradation, and how repeated cycles using the same PET caused damage to the polymer framework. The final conclusion made by the previous project manager was that the carboxylic acid end of the monomer would incorrectly degrade to a vinyl end when the polymer was broken apart. This would then react with any water in the system to form an alcohol end, and thus the monomer was no longer able to react in the same way. The reason for this degradation was simply shear stress and strain from the high pressures and temperatures within the system.

My role was to carry this forward. When I took over the project, there were two issues to tackle. The first was that the degradation of PET resulted in many other products being mixed in to the plastic which were able to diffuse into any liquids stored inside it. One of these chemicals was acetaldehyde, and causes a fruity 'off' taste to any liquids stored inside, with a human detection threshold of 60 ppb. Currently, this is removed using anthaniliamide in a 1:1 chemical reaction, which is 70% effective. The abatement of acetaldehyde was considered the priority goal.
The second goal was to try and improve the quality of the PET by reducing degradation. This would make it effective for many more PET cycles.

At the project start, the equipment used to synthesise PET plastics was new. This means that with an operating lifetime of 15 to 20 years, changing the equipment in any way was not possible, and so I had to find a way to achieve my goal without needing any additional engineering. This made me gravitate towards using a heterogeneous catalysis first, as these are easy to remove from feedstocks. 

When I took over this project, I had a meeting with members from two companies that would work together collaboratively on this. The first meeting was to discuss what possible routes that could be taken to succeed with our objectives. We discussed the machinery and the equipment that we could work with - how it works, the conditions inside, limitations - and we came up with a list of things that could be altered during the process. 

The next stage was the information research stage, which I performed independently. This was looking up any information to see if something like this had been done before, and starting to build an information bank to identify any patterns between materials.

Next was the testing phase. A model reactor was built to test the interactions of acetaldehyde over any potential catalysts that had been identified. A gas-phase reactor with a fixed bed was chosen, with a built-in GC-MS to monitor the gas feed to determine how active the catalyst was, how much acetaldehyde was removed, and what products were formed. 1000 ppm of acetaldehyde in argon was chosen as the feed gas mixture to mimic the low concentrations and 'inert' atmospheres (ie total oxidation not possible) of the extruder that is used for reprocessing.
During this phase we tested many different heterogeneous catalysts, from metal oxides and mixed metal oxides, to zeolites, to supported nanoparticles. Once we had an idea of what worked and what didn't, we moved on to the next phase.

The next phase was the incorporation or scale-up phase. Here, we tested our catalysts in the synthesis of PET bottles, which involved making the preform and blowing them to 2 L bottles. We then analysed everything we could about the PET that formed - colour, strength, haze, and of course content of acetaldehyde. The important part here was to determine whether our catalysts actually were able to operate for their intended purposes. Here, only a small number of catalysts proved to be viable, and were nowhere near the 70% benchmark that we had set. Those that showed promise were evaluated and taken back to the testing phase in the model reactor. 

Once catalysts had been pushed to their limits in both the testing and scale-up phases, we evaluated why this might be the case. We looked back to PET plastics and found that some resins were made with antimony metal, while others were made with Nickel. We doped samples of each catalyst with both metals, and re-ran some tests. While those doped with antimony saw the reactivity decrease to almost 0% in every case, those doped with nickel were unaffected. As a final part of the evaluation stage, we tried our catalyst on nickel resins. We found that while the catalyst cleared more acetaldehyde molecules from the PET of nickel resins, it still removed the same percentage of acetaldehyde from both (nickel resins tend to produce up to 50 ppm of acetaldehyde, while antimony resins only produce 10 ppm at maximum). This meant that it was more likely that our catalysts were mobility limited within the reaction stream - this made sense as they were more dense than the PET, so likely sank to the bottom.

The final stage of my involvement in this project was to set some future goals and to summarise what needed to be done for this project to succeed. I concluded that the heterogeneous catalysts we tested had great potential - they clearly removed acetaldehyde from the waste stream, and some of them also catalysed the breakdown of PET using much lower temperatures. I also established why this might be, and set frameworks for the next catalysts that should be produced. I also looked at alternative places where catalysts could be employed and found that one other area is during the blowing of the PET mould, where it is heated to 130 Celsius using IR radiation at approximately 1100nm in wavelength. I found other materials that act as a catalyst only in the presence of IR, and suggested these for the future project leader.

Ultimately, my role in this was to oversee the project from:
Conception > Research > Testing > Scale-up > Evaluation > Conclusions/Future Suggestions
and I would say that I succeeded in this.
